verses.verse: ((3 Whoredom is forbidden,9 And prodigality.15 He willeth a man to live on his labors and to help others,18 To love his wife.22 The wicked taken in their own wickedness.) ) My son, hearken unto my wisdom, and incline thine ear unto my (Or, understanding.) knowledge,
That thou mayest regard counsel, and thy lips observe knowledge.

For the lips (That is, an harlot which giveth herself to another than to her husband.) of a strange woman drop as an honeycomb, and her mouth is more soft than (By oil and honey he meaneth flattering and crafty enticements.) oil.
But the end of her is bitter as wormwood, and sharp as a two-edged sword.
Her (All her doings lead to destruction.) feet go down to death, and her steps take hold on hell.
She weigheth not the way of life: (She hath ever new means to allure to wickedness.) her paths are moveable: thou canst not know them.
Hear ye me now therefore, O children, and depart not from the words of my mouth.
Keep thy way far from her, and come not near the door of her house,
Lest thou give thine (That is, thy strength and goods to her that will have no pity upon thee: as is read of Samson, and the prodigal son.) honor unto others, and thy years to the cruel:
Lest the stranger should be filled with thy strength, and thy (The goods gotten by thy travel.) labors be in the house of a stranger,
And thou mourn at thine end, (when thou hast consumed thy flesh and thy body)
And say, How have I hated instruction, and mine heart despised correction!
And have not obeyed the voice of them that taught me, nor inclined mine ear to them that instructed me!

I was almost brought into all evil in the midst of the Congregation and (Although I was faithfully instructed in the truth, yet had I almost fallen to utter shame and destruction notwithstanding my good bringing up in the assembly of the godly.) assembly.
¶ Drink the water of (He teacheth us sobriety, exhorting us to live of our own labors and to be beneficial to the godly that want.) thy cistern, and of the rivers out of the midst of thine own well.
Let thy fountains flow forth, and the rivers of waters in the streets.

But let them be thine, even (Distribute them not to the wicked and infidels, but reserve them for thyself, thy family and them that are of the household of faith.) thine only, and not the strangers with thee.

Let thy (Thy children which shall come of thee in great abundance, showing that God blesseth marriage, and curseth whoredom.) fountain be blessed, and rejoice with the wife of thy (Which thou didst marry in thy youth.) youth.
Let her be as the loving hind and pleasant roe: let her breasts satisfy thee at all times, and delight in her love continually.
For why shouldest thou (Or, go astray with a stranger?) delight, my son, in a strange woman, or embrace the bosom of a stranger?

For the ways of man are before the (He declareth that except man do join to his wife both in heart and in outward conversation, that he shall not escape the judgments of God.) eyes of the Lord, and he pondereth all his paths.
His own iniquities shall take the wicked himself, and he shall be holden with the cords of his own sin.
He shall (Because he will not give ear to God’s word and be admonished.) die for fault of instruction, and shall go astray through his great folly.
